title: Sean Panikkar’s star is rising in the world of opera
text:
Sean Panikkar star as Rudolfo in MOT’s “La Boheme.” 
Sean Panikkar has the plum lead tenor role of Rodolfo in Michigan Opera Theatre’s presentation of Puccini’s “La Boheme,” but 15 years ago you needed a pair of binoculars to see him in the same opera at the Detroit Opera House.
Panikkar, 34, was then a sophomore studying music at the University of Michigan and sang in the chorus.
“It was my first paid singing job, and I was singing as a baritone,” he recalls between rehearsals at the Detroit Opera House.
“I don’t think I was really a baritone. Back then, I was a tenor who didn’t have high notes. I was so green.”
Since then Panikkar has ripened mightily as an artist.
After getting his master’s in music at UM, Panikkar was accepted into the Merola training program at San Francisco Opera.
Then his career ignited like a Roman candle. In addition to regional companies, Panikkar has sung at the Met in New York and La Scala in Milan.
That’s a huge leap from his high school graduation, where Panikkar got his first standing ovation after singing “You’ll Never Walk Alone.”
But nothing prepared him for the recognition he’d receive when he joined the crossover group Forte. In 2013 the group competed on “America’s Got Talent,” sending audiences swooning with their interpretations of “Unchained Melody” and “Somewhere.”
They came in fourth place, but that television exposure got the group (which includes tenors Josh Page and Hana Ryu) plenty of gigs, including Carnegie Hall.
Panikkar says he doesn’t prepare any differently whether it’s opera or Forte’s “popera” concerts.
“I warm up the same way,” he says. “My role in Forte is to be the opera singer in the group and sound like it. I never had to change the way I sang.”
In “La Boheme,” Panikkar is singing opposite soprano Nicole Cabell, who plays his love interest, Mimi. He says they have a good rapport.
“All of our instincts as Rodolfo and Mimi are completely in line,” he says. That’s not always the case.”
Born of Sri Lankan heritage in Bloomsburg, Pensylvannia, Panikkar studied violin, piano and trombone and sang in choir, but he didn’t seriously think he’d pursue a musical career. When he enrolled at UM, it was as a double major: civil engineering and music.
“My original goal was civil engineering as an undergrad and then a master’s in architecture,” he says. “I wanted to have my own construction company.”
Instead of building structures, Panikkar ended up building a towering musical career. He says he really got interested in opera when Daniel Washington, one of his teachers at UM, gave him a recording of Canadian tenor Jon Vickers. Panikkar was hooked on opera.
“What I loved was the way he inhabited the role, not just physically but in his voice; it was communicated so effectively,” he says.
Being an opera star requires a delicate balancing act when you’re also a husband and father, as Panikkar is. He’s married to Jane, a choral director at Concordia University in Ann Arbor. They’re the parents of Maria, 7, and Mark, 4, and make their home in Saline, southwest of Ann Arbor.
“I love being a dad,” he explains. “I’d take them everywhere if I could.”

MOT’s ‘La Boheme’ 
7:30 p.m. Oct. 17-25.
Detroit Opera House
1526 Broadway, Detroit
Sean Panikkar and Nicole Cabell sing Oct. 17, 21 and 24. Alternating in their roles Oct. 25 are Eric Margiore and Lina Tetriani.
Tickets: $29-$149.
(313) 874-SING
